channel.title: Nature - quantum
channel.description: Recent articles from Nature, Nature Physics, and Nature Photonics on Quantum Simulation.

item.title: The international measurement system beyond 2030
item.author: Wynand Louw, Gert Rietveld
item.content:encoded:
Measurements play a crucial role in our daily lives; and we rely on metrology to ensure that measurements are accurate and comparable. Celebrating the 150th anniversary of the beginning of the global measurement system, we look into its future.

Wynand Louw, Gert Rietveld

Nature Physics - Comments & Opinion

item.title: Quantum error correction of qudits beyond break-even
item.author: Benjamin L. Brock, Shraddha Singh, Michel H. Devoret
item.content:encoded:
Quantum error correction of a logical qutrit and ququart were experimentally realized beyond the break-even point with the Gottesman–Kitaev–Preskill bosonic code.

Benjamin L. Brock, Shraddha Singh, Michel H. Devoret

Nature - Research

item.title: Tunable vacuum-field control of fractional and integer quantum Hall phases
item.author: Josefine Enkner, Lorenzo Graziotto, Jérôme Faist
item.content:encoded:
Using a system to adjust the strength of cavity vacuum fields penetrating a Hall bar, a study describes the effect of the vacuum field of a cavity on electronic correlations in quantum Hall systems.

Josefine Enkner, Lorenzo Graziotto, Jérôme Faist

Nature - Research

item.title: Bulk–spatiotemporal vortex correspondence in gyromagnetic zero-index media
item.author: Ruo-Yang Zhang, Xiaohan Cui, C. T. Chan
item.content:encoded:
Realization of a gyromagnetic double-zero-index metamaterial results in unconventional optical and topological properties, suitable to be used for the generation of light pulses shaped as a vortex both in time and space.

Ruo-Yang Zhang, Xiaohan Cui, C. T. Chan

Nature - Research

item.title: Photon bunching in high-harmonic emission controlled by quantum light
item.author: Samuel Lemieux, Sohail A. Jalil, Giulio Vampa
item.content:encoded:
When high-harmonic emission from a ZnO crystal is perturbed with a bright squeezed vacuum beam, a comb of super-bunched high-order sidebands is created. This indicates photon bunching and the generation of a non-coherent state at the short wavelength.

Samuel Lemieux, Sohail A. Jalil, Giulio Vampa

Nature Photonics - Research

item.title: Why bad philosophy is stopping progress in physics
item.author: Carlo Rovelli
item.content:encoded:
Theoretical physicists are in thrall to a misguided mindset that allows viable ideas to be advanced only by overturning what already exists.

Carlo Rovelli

Nature - Comments & Opinion

item.title: Quantum cluster states engineered in three dimensions
item.author: Olivier Pfister
item.content:encoded:
The experimental realization of a 3D cluster quantum state paves the way for information processing employing quantum error correction.

Olivier Pfister

Nature Photonics - News & Views

item.title: Twisting entangled photons on a chip
item.author: Filippo Cardano, Lorenzo Marrucci
item.content:encoded:
A programmable quantum chip has been developed that generates, manipulates, and launches five-dimensional entangled photons into free-space channels, encoded as optical vortex modes, thus bridging the worlds of integrated and free-space quantum photonics.

Filippo Cardano, Lorenzo Marrucci

Nature Photonics - News & Views

item.title: Superconductivity and spin canting in spin–orbit-coupled trilayer graphene
item.author: Caitlin L. Patterson, Owen I. Sheekey, Andrea F. Young
item.content:encoded:
Introducing spin–orbit coupling by substrate proximity effect leads to an enhancement of superconducting phases in rhombohedral trilayer graphene.

Caitlin L. Patterson, Owen I. Sheekey, Andrea F. Young

Nature - Research

item.title: Twist-programmable superconductivity in spin–orbit-coupled bilayer graphene
item.author: Yiran Zhang, Gal Shavit, Stevan Nadj-Perge
item.content:encoded:
The superconductivity in Bernal bilayer graphene that emerges from the spin–orbit coupling induced by proximal tungsten diselenide can be tuned by modulating the twist angle between the two materials.

Yiran Zhang, Gal Shavit, Stevan Nadj-Perge

Nature - Research

item.title: Fractional charges under the microscope
item.author: Haojie Guo, Miguel M. Ugeda
item.content:encoded:
Fractionalized excitations typically require ultra-clean materials at low temperature and high magnetic field to emerge. Experiments on a simple graphene platform now reveal ideal conditions for the visualization of these fragile collective states.

Haojie Guo, Miguel M. Ugeda

Nature Physics - News & Views

item.title: Strongly interacting Meissner phases in large bosonic flux ladders
item.author: Alexander Impertro, SeungJung Huh, Monika Aidelsburger
item.content:encoded:
The quantum simulation of driven, strongly correlated phases at large scales is challenging, primarily due to detrimental heating effects. Now, a large-scale interacting Mott–Meissner phase has been realized in a neutral atom quantum simulator.

Alexander Impertro, SeungJung Huh, Monika Aidelsburger

Nature Physics - Research

item.title: Trump proposes unprecedented budget cuts to US science
item.author: Jeff Tollefson, Dan Garisto, Alexandra Witze
item.content:encoded:
Huge reductions, if enacted, could have ‘catastrophic’ effects on US competitiveness and the scientific pipeline, critics say.

Jeff Tollefson, Dan Garisto, Alexandra Witze

Nature - News

item.title: Collective quench dynamics of active photonic lattices in synthetic dimensions
item.author: Alexander Dikopoltsev, Ina Heckelmann, Jérôme Faist
item.content:encoded:
Synthetic dimensions allow photons and gauge fields to interact in photonic emulators. Now a study with fast-gain lasers shows that gain-driven coherence enables robust light flow in frequency space, establishing it as a viable platform for lattice emulation.

Alexander Dikopoltsev, Ina Heckelmann, Jérôme Faist

Nature Physics - Research

item.title: Ultracompact multibound-state-assisted flat-band lasers
item.author: Jieyuan Cui, Song Han, Qi Jie Wang
item.content:encoded:
A laser design that exploits multiple bound states on a flat band to tightly confine light in three dimensions yields an ultracompact terahertz quantum cascade laser cavity with a lateral size of ~3λ.

Jieyuan Cui, Song Han, Qi Jie Wang

Nature Photonics - Research

item.title: Quantum communication across a 250-kilometre optical-fibre network
item.author: Unknown Author
item.content:encoded:
Quantum communication over long distances can be achieved by exploiting a property of light called coherence. The coherence-based exchange of a ‘quantum encryption key’ over an optical telecommunications network demonstrates the feasibility of implementing a large-scale quantum network in existing telecommunications infrastructure.

Unknown Author

Nature - News & Views

item.title: Long-distance coherent quantum communications in deployed telecom networks
item.author: Mirko Pittaluga, Yuen San Lo, Andrew J. Shields
item.content:encoded:
A twin-field quantum key distribution protocol based on optical coherence is deployed over a 254-kilometre commercial telecom network, demonstrating that coherence-based quantum communication can be aligned with existing telecommunication infrastructure.

Mirko Pittaluga, Yuen San Lo, Andrew J. Shields

Nature - Research

item.title: Control of spin currents by magnon interference in a canted antiferromagnet
item.author: Lutong Sheng, Anna Duvakina, Haiming Yu
item.content:encoded:
Controlling the propagation of spin currents with opposite polarities in antiferromagnets has remained challenging. Now the frequency of coherently excited spin waves in a haematite-based device is shown to control the sign of the spin current.

Lutong Sheng, Anna Duvakina, Haiming Yu

Nature Physics - Research

item.title: Scalable microwave-to-optical transducers at the single-photon level with spins
item.author: Tian Xie, Rikuto Fukumori, Andrei Faraon
item.content:encoded:
Converting photons from one frequency range to another uses nonlinear effects that are often weak. Strong nonlinearities in rare-earth-ion-doped crystals have now been used to perform microwave-to-optical transduction at the single-photon level.

Tian Xie, Rikuto Fukumori, Andrei Faraon

Nature Physics - Research

item.title: Don’t believe the hype — quantum tech can’t yet solve real-world problems
item.author: Joan Arrow
item.content:encoded:
Investors and the public should know what quantum devices can and, more importantly, can’t do.

Joan Arrow

Nature - Comments & Opinion

item.title: Antiferromagnetic quantum anomalous Hall effect under spin flips and flops
item.author: Zichen Lian, Yongchao Wang, Yayu Wang
item.content:encoded:
A new device based on 7-septuple-layer MnBi2Te4 covered with an AlOx capping layer enables the investigation of antiferromagnetic quantum anomalous Hall effect over wide parameter spaces.

Zichen Lian, Yongchao Wang, Yayu Wang

Nature - Research

item.title: Observation of the axion quasiparticle in 2D MnBi2Te4
item.author: Jian-Xiang Qiu, Barun Ghosh, Su-Yang Xu
item.content:encoded:
The dynamical axion quasiparticle, which is directly analogous to the hypothetical fundamental axion particle, is observed in two-dimensional MnBi2Te4, and has implications for quantum chromodynamics, cosmology and string theory.

Jian-Xiang Qiu, Barun Ghosh, Su-Yang Xu

Nature - Research

item.title: Hamiltonian engineering of collective XYZ spin models in an optical cavity
item.author: Chengyi Luo, Haoqing Zhang, James K. Thompson
item.content:encoded:
Spin models that can be emulated by quantum simulators are usually restricted to systems with conserved total magnetization. The tuning of photon-mediated interactions between atoms in a cavity enables the implementation of more general models also useful for quantum sensing tasks.

Chengyi Luo, Haoqing Zhang, James K. Thompson

Nature Physics - Research

item.title: A terahertz-bandwidth non-magnetic isolator
item.author: Haotian Cheng, Yishu Zhou, Peter T. Rakich
item.content:encoded:
Researchers demonstrated integrated non-magnetic isolators with 24.5-dB contrast, –2.16-dB insertion loss and 2-THz (16-nm) optical bandwidth.

Haotian Cheng, Yishu Zhou, Peter T. Rakich

Nature Photonics - Research

item.title: Impact of impurities on crystal growth
item.author: Qiong Gao, Huang Fang, Peng Tan
item.content:encoded:
Crystallization processes are influenced by the presence of impurities. Colloid experiments now reveal two distinct types of growth mode that depend on the extent to which a crystallizing system can remove impurity particles from its growth front.

Qiong Gao, Huang Fang, Peng Tan

Nature Physics - Research

item.title: Observation of antiferromagnetic order in a quasicrystal
item.author: R. Tamura, T. Abe, T. J. Sato
item.content:encoded:
Quasicrystals lack translational symmetry but display rotational order. Whether antiferromagnetic order can exist in quasicrystals has been unclear. Now, long-range antiferromagnetic order is shown in the icosahedral quasicrystal Au56In28.5Eu15.5.

R. Tamura, T. Abe, T. J. Sato

Nature Physics - Research

item.title: How the United States became a science superpower — and how quickly it could crumble
item.author: Steve Blank
item.content:encoded:
US global dominance in science was no accident, but a product of a far-seeing partnership between public and private sectors to boost innovation and economic growth.

Steve Blank

Nature - Comments & Opinion

item.title: Continuous recoil-driven lasing and cavity frequency pinning with laser-cooled atoms
item.author: Vera M. Schäfer, Zhijing Niu, James K. Thompson
item.content:encoded:
Experiments with cold atoms in optical cavities are often limited to discontinuous operation due to reloading requirements. Now, continuous lasing is demonstrated with strontium atoms in a ring cavity, stabilized by atom loss mechanisms.

Vera M. Schäfer, Zhijing Niu, James K. Thompson

Nature Physics - Research

item.title: Daily briefing: Mysterious Taiwan fossil is Denisovan
item.author: Flora Graham
item.content:encoded:
A fossilized jawbone discovered more than 20 years ago belonged to a Denisovan. Plus, the states hit hardest by NIH cuts in charts and an acoustics lab inside an abandoned nuclear plant.

Flora Graham

Nature - News

item.title: ‘Mind blowing’: quantum computer untangles the mathematics of knots
item.author: Davide Castelvecchi
item.content:encoded:
Algorithms for studying knots and other topological objects could have a quantum advantage.

Davide Castelvecchi

Nature - News

item.title: Concurrent spin squeezing and field tracking with machine learning
item.author: Junlei Duan, Zhiwei Hu, Yanhong Xiao
item.content:encoded:
Simultaneous spin squeezing and the detection of dynamic fields is challenging as entanglement generation and signal interrogation often interfere. An experiment now demonstrates stable spin squeezing and field tracking in a hot atomic ensemble.

Junlei Duan, Zhiwei Hu, Yanhong Xiao

Nature Physics - Research

item.title: Resourceful dissipation
item.author: Yann Kiefer
item.content:encoded:
Controlled dissipation enables the extraction of equilibrium properties of ultracold one-dimensional gases through the observation of anomalous dynamics.

Yann Kiefer

Nature Physics - News & Views

item.title: The strongly driven Fermi polaron
item.author: Franklin J. Vivanco, Alexander Schuckert, Nir Navon
item.content:encoded:
Fermi polarons are quasiparticles formed by impurities immersed in a Fermi gas. An experiment in an ultracold fermionic gas now shows how to control their properties with a tunable radio-frequency field.

Franklin J. Vivanco, Alexander Schuckert, Nir Navon

Nature Physics - Research

item.title: Space-time-topological events in photonic quantum walks
item.author: Joshua Feis, Sebastian Weidemann, Alexander Szameit
item.content:encoded:
Combining space topology and time topology, topological states that are localized simultaneously in space and time are theoretically and experimentally demonstrated, potentially enabling the space-time topological shaping of light waves with applications in spatiotemporal wave control for imaging, communications and topological lasers.

Joshua Feis, Sebastian Weidemann, Alexander Szameit

Nature Photonics - Research

item.title: Hybrid entanglement and bit-flip error correction in a scalable quantum network node
item.author: Xiu-Ying Chang, Pan-Yu Hou, Lu-Ming Duan
item.content:encoded:
Nodes in a quantum network must be able to interface with photonic qubits as well as perform local quantum computations. The quantum node device presented here is capable of storing quantum information and correcting bit-flip errors.

Xiu-Ying Chang, Pan-Yu Hou, Lu-Ming Duan

Nature Physics - Research

item.title: Exploiting 2D materials
item.author: Rachel Won
item.content:encoded:
Two-dimensional materials have revolutionized the field of photonics by enabling the manipulation of light at the nanoscale. As their potential continues to grow, we can expect to see more innovative applications emerging in the future.

Rachel Won

Nature Photonics - News & Views

item.title: Intertwining with Fourier optics
item.author: José Azaña
item.content:encoded:
An angular Fourier optics framework has been established and demonstrated, unlocking unprecedented opportunities for the analysis and manipulation of light waves carrying orbital angular momentum.

José Azaña

Nature Photonics - News & Views

item.title: Coherent control of a superconducting qubit using light
item.author: Hana K. Warner, Jeffrey Holzgrafe, Marko Lončar
item.content:encoded:
Superconducting qubits operate at microwave frequencies, but it is much more efficient to transmit information optically. Now, a superconducting qubit has been controlled with an optical signal by using a microwave–optical quantum transducer.

Hana K. Warner, Jeffrey Holzgrafe, Marko Lončar

Nature Physics - Research

item.title: Near-field photon entanglement in total angular momentum
item.author: Amit Kam, Shai Tsesses, Guy Bartal
item.content:encoded:
Non-classical correlations between two photons in the near-field regime give rise to entanglement in their total angular momentum, leading to a completely different structure of quantum correlations of photon pairs.

Amit Kam, Shai Tsesses, Guy Bartal

Nature - Research

item.title: A qudit quantum computer for simulation of two-dimensional quantum electrodynamics
item.author: Unknown Author
item.content:encoded:
Quantum electrodynamics (QED) is a cornerstone of the standard model of particle physics. A decade-long effort to simulate QED on a two-dimensional lattice has now succeeded — through the use of a trapped-ion quantum computer based on multidimensional ‘qudits’, which are uniquely suited to the challenge.

Unknown Author

Nature Physics - News & Views

item.title: Certified randomness using a trapped-ion quantum processor
item.author: Minzhao Liu, Ruslan Shaydulin, Marco Pistoia
item.content:encoded:
Certifiably random bits can be generated using the 56-qubit Quantinuum H2-1 trapped-ion quantum computer accessed over the Internet.

Minzhao Liu, Ruslan Shaydulin, Marco Pistoia

Nature - Research

item.title: The limits of quantum correlations
item.author: Thinh P. Le
item.content:encoded:
Measurements on quantum particles produce random outcomes whose correlations can sometimes never be explained by classical physics. The complete set of possible quantum correlations for two particles under two measurements has now been identified.

Thinh P. Le

Nature Physics - News & Views

item.title: Daily briefing: Why RNA hasn’t yet had its ‘AlphaFold’ moment
item.author: Flora Graham
item.content:encoded:
Protein-structure-prediction tools have transformed biology, but RNA is a tougher nut to crack. Plus, the NIH is cancelling COVID-19 research funds and how ‘qudits’ can boost quantum computing.

Flora Graham

Nature - News

item.title: Quantum statistics in the minimal Bell scenario
item.author: Victor Barizien, Jean-Daniel Bancal
item.content:encoded:
A complete theoretical understanding of many simple problems in quantum physics is still lacking, especially when entanglement is involved. Now the full set of possible observations has been established for a minimal scenario of shared entanglement.

Victor Barizien, Jean-Daniel Bancal

Nature Physics - Research

item.title: Mathematician who reshaped theory of symmetry wins Abel Prize
item.author: Davide Castelvecchi
item.content:encoded:
Masaki Kashiwara is the first Japanese person to be awarded the most prestigious prize in mathematics.

Davide Castelvecchi

Nature - News

item.title: Macrophages harness hepatocyte glutamate to boost liver regeneration
item.author: María del Mar Rigual, Mariana Angulo-Aguado, Nabil Djouder
item.content:encoded:
Glutamate metabolically reprograms bone-marrow-derived macrophages, stabilizing HIF1α, which transcriptionally activates WNT3 to promote YAP1-dependent hepatocyte proliferation, boosting liver regeneration.

María del Mar Rigual, Mariana Angulo-Aguado, Nabil Djouder

Nature - Research

item.title: Simulating two-dimensional lattice gauge theories on a qudit quantum computer
item.author: Michael Meth, Jinglei Zhang, Martin Ringbauer
item.content:encoded:
Qubit-based simulations of gauge theories are challenging as gauge fields require high-dimensional encoding. Now a quantum electrodynamics model has been demonstrated using trapped-ion qudits, which encode information in multiple states of ions.

Michael Meth, Jinglei Zhang, Martin Ringbauer

Nature Physics - Research

item.title: Meet ‘qudits’: more complex cousins of qubits boost quantum computing
item.author: Davide Castelvecchi
item.content:encoded:
Working with multi-dimensional entities could make calculations more efficient and reduce errors.

Davide Castelvecchi

Nature - News

item.title: Deterministic remote entanglement using a chiral quantum interconnect
item.author: Aziza Almanakly, Beatriz Yankelevich, William D. Oliver
item.content:encoded:
Large quantum computers are likely to require methods of connecting devices by transmitting and absorbing photons. Entanglement between two superconducting qubit devices has now been established using a waveguide with tunable directionality.

Aziza Almanakly, Beatriz Yankelevich, William D. Oliver

Nature Physics - Research

item.title: Daily briefing: Babies make memories — so why don’t we recall them?
item.author: Flora Graham
item.content:encoded:
Babies as young as one year old can form memories, our adult brains just can’t access them. Plus, US-funded researchers outside the United States are being grilled about ideology and physicists suggest a ‘crazy’ new way we could generate electricity.

Flora Graham

Nature - News
